questionText: What is the metaphoric meaning of silo?

with fermenting seems to be missing in these explanations', "the origin of the metaphor is the idea that grain silos don't communicate with each other", "This becomes problematic when the direction of strange metaphor for isolation', 'A term used within business process re-engineering (BPR) to denote areas within an organization where managers occupy a privileged position in terms of resources and influence, and where they use this for their own, self-interested, functionally-oriented motives rather than for the wider benefit of the business.', 'Silo is a metaphor', 'Process-oriented organizations break down the barriers of structural departments', 'A functional group or department within an organization acts as a silo or island in its lack of interaction with other groups and in "It's a fermenting over time, away from the rest of the influences", 'Poorly operated silos become structurally unsound and can lead to a collapse or worse', 'A functional silo in an organization or ['Silos are good when properly operated']]

questionText: What's the difference between an -ing noun and a real noun
clusters: [['It is OK to use developing as a noun', 'Its substantival nature is shown by its ability to take an attributive adjective.', 'In general, you can generate a noun that refers to the process of the verb', 'These should be used at the appropriate situations.', '"developing" is not a noun.', "Even if you can generate an -ing noun from a verb, there's no reason to assume it would mean the same thing as a noun ending with -ment generated from the same verb", "An '-ing' can be added to create a new noun", 'A gerund would normally have in it the verbal nature which the corresponding noun does not have.', 'Its substantival nature is shown by its ability to take a definite or an indefinite article.', 'In the case of "developing" one might compare "The development of AIDS in Africa has proved to be one of the biggest tragedies in the Third World" vs "The new president aims at developing the country\'s poor-relief system".', 'Many verbs have many corresponding nouns', "The noun form of verbs by adding '-ing' are called gerunds.", "It's not a universal rule", 'Development is a noun', 'If development refers to a single major development such as a shopping mall, then developing is not possible', 'You cannot say, I am going for a swimming.', 'Some verbs have corresponding nouns', 'Its verbal nature is shown by the fact that it can have a subject.', 'You cannot use any word anywhere you feel like, while writing in English.', 'Its substantival nature is shown by its ability to be the object of a preposition.', "If they always meant the same thing, we wouldn't need different suffixes", 'Developing is also a noun', 'Develop is a verb', 'You have to say, Swimming is his hobby.', 'Developing is the gerund form of the verb develop', 'In parallel cases a noun ending in -ment would normally imply the result of an action, the product of an action while the corresponding gerund would refer to the action itself.', 'Its substantival nature is shown by the fact that it can take a plural ending.', 'You can definitely say, I am going for a swim.', "When do I use gerunds and not the 'normal noun' form? Well, that comes with practice.", 'In cases where there is no alternative, the sentence sounds fine', 'Its verbal nature is shown by its ability to take a direct and an indirect object.', 'The second sentence here is grammatical', 'You cannot say, Swim is his hobby.', 'The reason it sounds strange is partly because the whole concept is a little fuzzy, but mostly because we have a perfectly good and common alternative to developing: development', 'Developing is a noun but not the one you think', 'You can sometimes generate a noun by adding -ing', 'Development is the noun form'], ['Its verbal nature is shown by its ability to appear in different tenses.'], ['The active form of a gerund is often used in a passive sense.'], ['They thought that Tom would bring a big development for this small town is the correct one.']]

questionText: How do inversions of extended chords work?

questionText: How do you decide whether to use the infinitive or -ing version of a verb?
clusters: [['avoiding implies something continuous and ongoing', 'to avoid is a series of individual events', '"She started avoiding me" sounds like "I walked in the room and she immediately left, and when I followed her she left the building."', '"She started to avoid me" sounds like "I called her and she didn\'t return my call. The next day I texted her but she didn\'t text back. Two days later I sent her an email which she never opened."'], ['Other uses of those forms influence how we perceive both options even in cases where both are grammatically equivalent', 'I wonder: is there any way to decide whether to use the former or the latter?', 'the nuance of difference is so subtle that you could use either purely depending on which one you liked the sound of', 'There are a number of other factors to bias the decision', 'Begin and start can be followed by infinitives or -ing forms', 'I search for the phrase with the most results in Google Books', 'Three months had passed since she started saving money', 'Both constructs are equally valid from a grammatical point of view'], ['After progressive forms of begin and start, infinitives are preferred'], ['Infinitives are also preferred with stative verbs like understand, realise and know'], ['Three months had passed since she started to save money'], ['you use the infinitive for activities that you plan, think, want, start to do, that is that lie in the future of the thinking, starting and so on, but have not yet begun'], ['you use the past or present continuous for events that are ongoing in the present or had been ongoing until a specified end point or for a specified duration'], ['the proper use is reflected in the following example: Three months have passed since she has started to avoid me, and she has been avoiding me ever since']]

questionText: Serial to USB converter
clusters: [['If a computer does something like send a single character, and wait for the peripheral to respond before sending the next, then the character rate is determined by the latency for two entire usb packets - one to send a single character, and one to receive one.', 'With legacy systems, you may get lucky and find it works fine, it may work but slowly, or it may not work reliably at all.', "In today's world where USB-serial converters are as or more common than real serial ports, it's important to design protocols so that you can send out a lot of data, before needing to wait for a reply.", 'If you try to move a lot of data in tiny pieces with USB, you lose - badly.', 'Other protocols which depend on constant back-and-forth of short messages or single characters between a computer and a serial peripheral can slow to a crawl (or even mis-operate) when used with a usb-serial converter.', 'USB is inherently packet-oriented, with comparably high-latency.', 'Classic serial ports are ordinarily byte-oriented, ie, one character at a time with quite low latency.', 'Anything (hardware or even client software) designed to use a serial port should be tested for usability with usb-serial converters early enough in its development that the design can be changed to fix any issues discovered.', "USB is great for moving a lot of data at once, but it's actually slower at moving tiny amounts of data.", 'For just typing on a terminal program talking to a modem or an embedded device, or even uploading files, etc, this is really not a problem, because single doses of the latency are small in human terms, and the USB can easily move blocks of data fast enough keep up with any serial baud rate.', 'My own previous simple win32 management tool for that device ran without apparent delay on the same laptop with the same converter.', "A piece of management software for an embedded device which had been written and tested by a contractor using a real serial port turned out to use some variation of .NET serial calls that turned out to be 'watch the results crawl in' slow on a laptop with a usb-serial converter."], ["The most common units (usually a 'cable' that plugs into a USB to know if your equipment is grossly non standard.', 'Most standard baud rates should be usable depending on the speed of the chip', 'Different cables may emulate more/less exactly', 'The quickest and easiest method, and possibly the equal best, is to buy an existing USB to serial converter.', 'The design of the client software matters.', 'I would require a Serial to USB converter'], ['PL2303HX is great and working without any issue'], ['Perhaps check the manual (if there is one) before buying'], ['Some manufacturers peripherals do strange things and may not work for all converters.'], ['You can build your own using any of several available custom ICs created for this purpose.', 'You need something like a FT232'], ['CP2102 is great and working without any issue']]

questionText: Why do many manuals and technical documents seem to prefer passive voice?
clusters: [["I may have to use 'The setting can be accessed in the widget' instead"], ['Many manuals and technical documents prefer passive voice over active voice', "The vast preponderance of the firm's tech docs were littered with egregious passive voice, as well as massive redundancies and an over-reliance on repeated heavily-bolded all caps warnings where there were use-case risks.", 'passive voice is often a last resort', 'The same thinking may still apply.', 'The use of passive voice and other issues in the tech docs was a result of the one class each engineer had been required to take in tech comms during university.', 'In academic writing, scientific papers and similar, it is normal practice to avoid writing in the first person', 'it is not a default standard any longer', 'This practice carries through to a large number of technical communications', 'There is no good practical reason for passive voice in technical communication', 'People will produce information designs that they would never use or like themselves just because they think those designs are conventional', 'If people are in a field where passive documentation is common, they may simply copy that style', 'There is a tendency to follow on from: The system does x to The system is affected by x rather than x affects the system', "People often feel that because documentation is a 'business document' it must be formal", 'The passive voice can be used to conceal the actor', 'When writing in the third person, the passive voice becomes more natural', 'It would be recommended to continue to use the general principle of minimising the use of the passive voice', 'At no less than ten top-flight US engineering programs, students were taught that passive voice would somehow help them magically evade liability and responsibility should an enduser be harmed in the use of their product.', "This tendency doesn't make the use of passive correct or preferred", "Communicators who seem unsure of themselves or who don't really want to communicate at all often take refuge in the passive to avoid taking or assigning responsibility"], ['I suspect this is true of other widely-used style guides as well'], ['The belief that passive voice would help engineers evade liability and responsibility is a baseless belief, belied by both competent writing and many years of case precedent.'], ['Once I presented studies, and brought in a risk-specialist attorney to explain this, we shifted language.'], ['I have avoided using passive voice as a default for the past 20 years'], ['I surreptitiously updated an entire suite of Standard Operating Procedures to active voice over the course of a few years'], ['older documentation is still hanging around or used as a base document for similar, new products without any thought (or time) to update it to active voice']]

questionText: What is the conversion for dotted quarters to bpm in 6/8 time?
clusters: [['6/8 does not change anything aside from the meter', 'Dotted quarter=72 IS 72 beats per minute', 'That equates to two clicks per bar, each click meaning three quavers', 'one plays the piece with 72 dotted quarters per minute or 216 eighth notes per minute', 'You would set a metronome to 72 (adagio) because this will click on the beats', 'You would not find a metronome clicking every 2/3 of the musical beat very helpful', 'You would count as 1-trip-let 2-trip-let :| or something similar emphasising the beats (numbers) only', 'The time signature 6/8 is compound duple', "It's good to train yourself to be able to make the change without changing the metronome marking.", 'Dotted-quarter=72 equates mathematically to 8th=216 (3X72) or quarter=108 (half of 216)', "It's manic", 'As you are playing, it may sometimes feel like two groups of three beats in a measure, and sometimes like two beats per measure.', "The 6/8 won't affect the tempo to play at", 'Set for 72bpm and recognise two clicks per bar', 'I want to know if 6/8 changes anything', 'In a 6/8 meter, you can either think of the eighth notes as the beat, in which case there will be six of them in a measure; or you can think of the dotted quarter as the beat, in which case there will be two of them in the measure.', 'If the tempo is given as a dotted crotchet = 72, this means there are 72 beats per minute, and (3x72=) 216 pulses per minute', 'If you set the metronome to three times that - 216bpm, it would be six clicks per bar - one for each quaver, were there six played in a particular bar', 'It would be 72 bpm', 'I have a piece that is set at dotted quarter=72 in 6/8 time', "I think it's best to be flexible about this, and realize that there is a duality."], ["A lot of metronomes, especially mechanical ones, won't quite reach that"], ['I want to know what this would be in bpm']]

questionText: When a sentence uses a parenthetical plural, should the rest of the sentence treat it as singular or plural?

verb should be plural', 'In those cases I prefer to recast the sentence', 'I try to avoid optional plurals', "To adhere perfectly to the convention (so that the text is readable even if no parentheses questionText: Why the use of resistors when pulling something up or down?

questionText: Why are numbers sometimes spelled out and then numerals specified as well?
